factText: Several wildfires are raging across California, destroying homes and forcing evacuations with more than 18 million people under a red flag warning in the state's south. 🙏🏻 50,000 people have been forced to evacuate in Healdsburg, Windsor and Geyserville. More than 83,000 people between Highway 101 and the Pacific Ocean were ordered to evacuate Saturday night as authorities grew increasingly concerned the Kincade fire could burn all the way to the coast.

Wildfires in California trigger state of emergency in Sonoma, Los Angeles counties https://t.co/ToACmjOhJf. Breaking: Mandatory evacuation zones for Kincade Fire were dramatically expanded from Healdsburg to Sonoma Coast include Guerneville, Jenner, Bodega Bay, Occidental, Forestville and more. California Declares State of Emergency to Fight Los Angeles, Sonoma Fires - Governor https://t.co/NEh9GPpcpU
San Francisco now rates almost entirely Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups #KincadeFire https://t.co/ruimVlrTVn

Wildfire in Sonoma County explodes to 10,000 acres, forces evacuations https://t.co/FTm93zK9fI. Crazy and scary that all of Healdsburg and Windsor are being evacuated. In northern California, wildfires in the Sonoma Valley forced more than 2,000 people to evacuate, while in southern California, a conflagration in Santa Clarita drove more than 50,000 from their homes. Mandatory evacuations have expanded into Sonoma County. Mandatory evacuations for the Kincade Fire in Sonoma County have expanded.

Dozens of homes have already been destroyed and thousands of residents displaced by the intense smoke and flames. Thousands evacuated Tens of thousands of people near Santa Clarita, north of Los Angeles, fled their homes on Friday as firefighters struggle to control fires that are spread over 4,000 acres (1,618 hectares). 2,000 people forced to evacuate as wildfire burns in Sonoma County

Los Angeles, United States – Millions face weekend blackout Authorities are preparing to cut power amid concerns that high-voltage power lines could cause additional blazes. Power shut-offs have begun. PG&E has begun to shutoff power in most of Sonoma County. 850 thousand PG&E customers could be losing power across Northern California. Millions across the state will be impacted by PG&E public safety power shut offs.

Authorities shut down all nearby schools on Friday as well as a major highway after the blaze continued to spread. Kincade Fire causes road closures in Sonoma County. The Soledad Canyon Road and Sand Canyon Road off-ramps will remain closed until further notice, Caltrans said. The freeway was closed early Friday morning when flames jumped the roadway.

Thousands of people have been evacuated as the wildfires continue to rage. The 925 firefighters remaining on the scene were putting out hot spots and continuing to clear containment lines of vegetation around the burn area to prepare for a new round of Santa Ana winds forecast for Sunday night into Monday, fire officials said.

Some Evacuations Lifted For Santa Clarita Tick Fire; 14 Freeway Partially Reopens - CBS Los Angeles
https://t.co/K4v7msJwYe

Kincade wildfire: dozens of buildings destroyed in Sonoma County https://t.co/oWEgmjf0I5 https://t.co/QLNx44T1Yy. Kincade Fire in Sonoma County Wipes Out Nearly 2 Dozen Homes https://t.co/MNhPBErymA via @nbcbayarea. Fires destroyed dozens of buildings in Northern California wine country and in subdivisions on the outskirts of Los Angeles, where flames shut down a freeway and smoke forced schools to close.

Wildfire activity in California has surged since Wednesday, from the massive Kincade Fire in Sonoma County to the Tick Fire in Los Angeles County. Californian officials have warned that "historic and extreme" wind conditions were set to fan raging wildfires in the north of the state as millions of residents face power cuts
As fire departments fight back the raging infernos, tens of thousands of people remain under evacuation orders for the second blaze-illuminated night.

JUST IN: #KincadeFire in Sonoma County now at 25,455 acres and is 10% contained, Cal Fire says. #KincadeFire 25,455 acres with 10% containment ~ Mark. https://t.co/zlp4vfi6c4. SONOMA COUNTY SHERIFF Alert: Mandatory evacuation ordered for The city of Healdsburg and Town of Windsor due to the Kincade fire. New mandatory evacuation zones in #KincadeFire include Healdsburg, Windsor.

As of 8:24am Airtack has done a fly over of the entire fire and will not be able to work any fixed wing aircraft until the smoke clears out later today, although helco will be working helicopters where capable.
The planned power outage could last for several days, in an attempt to prevent a "catastrophic wildfire" during what is expected to be particularly dry and windy weather.

factText: If you are an emergency responder and you or your family are being displaced by the #Kincadefire please contact us for assistance in locating shelter. No identification is needed to stay at an evacuation shelter, and English and Spanish-speaking staff will be there to make these safe, supportive places for all. Volunteers needed to help setup Finley Hall evacuation shelter for people with pets.

factText: ⚠️ Kincade Fire Update ⚠️ MANDATORY EVACUATIONS have been ordered from Hwy 101 in Geyserville all the way south to Hwy 101 in Windsor east of 101, which includes the entire City of Healdsburg and entire Town of Windsor.

The fire has already burned 20,000 acres and is only 10% contained. So far, the raging fire has destroyed more than 20,000 acres and is only 10 percent contained. factText: As of Saturday morning, the fire was 10% contained and had consumed 25,455 acres. At last check, the fire is 10 percent contained. Fire is 10% contained. Kincade Fire reaches 40 sq. miles, 11% containment (updated 7:27 pm). The fire that started at 1:24 p.m. Thursday was 55% contained today, it's size remained at 4,615 acres and 16 structures were found to have been damaged, Los Angeles County Fire Department officials said.
They need 30 bales of grass hay, 30 bales of straw, 30 shavings and 100 muck buckets, all items are to help with the animals of the Kincade Fire.

Nearly all of Sonoma County is now under mandatory evacuations OR evacuation warning. Evacuation Orders The mandatory evacuation area has been expanded to now include those areas previously under an evacuation warning. More evacuations have been ordered in Sonoma County: 90,000 residents have been told to leave. ***NEW EVACUATION ZONES*** Residents living WEST of Furlong Rd and NORTH of Bodega Hwy INCLUDING the community of Freestone are now under a MANDATORY EVACUATION notice.

factText: At the evacuations centers, our volunteers provide individuals and families safe a safe place to stay, food, and some comfort in the midst of the Kincade Fire evacuations. If you have been forced to evacuate due to the Kincade Fire, here is a list of centers in Sonoma County. If that's not an option, all of the evacuation centers in Santa Rosa and Petaluma (listed at the link above) are animal-friendly and can provide space!

Meanwhile residents are scrambling to prepare as more than two million people could lose power to prevent more devastation. Bay Area Air Quality Management District reminds us to spare the air and prepare for wildfire smoke. Such great planning for this fire event!

Thanks to many amazing volunteers from Napa CART, Napa CERT and Sunrise Horse Rescue we were able to set up over 100 temporary pens today at NAPA Valley Horseman Association and Valley Brook Equestrian Center so that if Napa CART is activated for the #KincadeFire or something new, we can receive animals at these shelter sites very quickly.
informationNeeds: CrisisFACTS-015_general_What volunteer efforts are currently active for {event}?

Sebastopol and parts North East of Santa Rosa have been moved to a watch status.

Authorities speak of the potential for a major explosion in the Kincade Fire tonight and Sunday should the winds reach the forecast maximums. Make sure you check out Sonoma Sheriff's live stream of tonight's press conference at 6:30pm for updates on the current Kincade fire conditions. The men and women of Lake County's law enforcement agencies are assisting Sonoma County with the #KincadeFire response.
